Oracle (ORCL) has just wrapped up its quarterly reporting period with impressive results . Revenue rose 11% year-over-year to $15.9 billion, beating expectations with ease . The real highlight was Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI), which surged 52% to reach $6.7 billion . Oracle continues to demonstrate resilience and leadership in both Cloud and AI .  A key driver behind Oracle’s Cloud momentum is its smartly executed multi-cloud strategy . MultiCloud database services used by customers on Amazon (AMZN), Microsoft Azure (MSFT), and Google Cloud (GOOGL) soared 115% quarter-over-quarter . This approach turns would-be rivals into collaborators .  Management attributed much of this backlog growth to major contracts with companies like OpenAI, Meta, Nvidia, and AMD . CEO Safra Catz expressed evident enthusiasm, projecting that Oracle’s Cloud business will grow by more than 40% in Fiscal 2026 .  Operating cash flow for the year reached an impressive $20.8 billion, providing the company with ample capacity to reinvest in future growth . With around $18 billion in cash and short-term investments, Oracle appears to have the financial flexibility to fund expansion without overburdening its balance sheet .
